537.05
907.01  DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter the following terms, phrases, words and
their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent
with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in
the plural include the singular, and words in the singular include the plural.
The word "shall" is mandatory and not merely directory:
   (a)   “Person” means any person, firm, partnership, association,
corporation, company or organization of any kind.
   (b)   “Street” or “highway” means the entire width of every public way,
easement or right-of-way when any part thereof is open to the use of the
public, as a matter of right, for the purposes of vehicular and pedestrian
traffic, and shall include alleys.
   (c)   “Public places” include all other grounds owned by the City.
   (d)   “Property line” means the outer edge of a street or highway or actual
parcel line.
   (e)   “Treelawn” means that part of a street or highway not covered by
sidewalk or other paving, lying between the property line and that portion of
the street or highway usually used for vehicular traffic.
   (f)   “Public trees” mean all shade and ornamental trees now or hereafter
growing on any street, highway or any public places.
   (g)   “Large trees” mean those attaining a height of forty-five feet or
more.
   (h)   “Medium trees” mean those attaining a height of thirty to forty-five
feet.
   (i)   “Small trees” mean those attaining a height of less than thirty feet.
   (j)   “Principal thoroughfare” means any street upon which trucks are not
prohibited.
(Ord. 73-36. Passed 6-19-73.)
907.02  ESTABLISHMENT OF SHADE TREE COMMISSION.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section 907.02 was repealed by Ordinance 2016-34,
passed November 1, 2016.)
907.03  POWERS OF SHADE TREE COMMISSION.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section 907.03 was repealed by Ordinance 2016-34,
passed November 1, 2016.)
907.04  PROHIBITED TREES AND SHRUBS.
   The following trees shall not be planted on Treelawns:
   Acer saccharinum (Silver maple)
   Acer negundo (Boxelder)
   Aesculus hippocastanum (Common Horse chestnut) unless seedless cultivars
   Ailanthus altissima(Tree of Heaven)
   Betula (all Birch)
   Catalpa (all Catalpa) unless seedless cultivars
   Morus (all Mulberry)
   Populus (all Poplars)
   Salix (all Willows)
   Ginkgo biloba (Ginkgo Females only)
   Fraxinus (all native Ash)
   Sorbus aucuparia (European Mountain ash)
   Robinia pseudooacacia (Black Locust)
   Malus pumila (Apple)
   Ulmus Americana ‘Moline’ (Moline Elm)
   Ulmus pumila (Siberian Elm)
   Populus deltoides  (Cottonwood)
   Pyrus calleryana (All Callery Pear)
   Whenever any tree or shrub shall be planted or set out in conflict with the
provisions of the section, it shall be lawful for the City Manager or his
designee to remove or cause removal of the same.
(Ord. 73-36. Passed 6-19-73.)
907.05  REMOVAL, REPLANTING AND REPLACEMENT.
   (a)   Wherever it is necessary to remove a tree or shrub from a treelawn in
connection with the paving of a sidewalk, or the paving or widening of a
portion of a street, alley or highway used for vehicular traffic, the City
shall replant such trees or shrubs, or replace them; provided, that it may be
satisfied if an equivalent number of trees or shrubs of the same size and
approved species as provided for by the Parks and Recreation Advisory Board are
planted in an attractive manner on the adjoining property.
   (b)   No person or property owner shall remove a tree or shrub from a
treelawn for the purpose of construction, or for any other reason without first
filing an application and obtaining a permit from the City Manager or designee
and without replacing the removed tree or shrub. Such replacement shall meet
the standards of size, species and placement as provided for in a permit issued
by the City Manager or designee. The person or property owner shall bear the
cost of removal and replacement of all trees or shrubs removed.
(Ord. 73-36. Passed 6-19-73; Ord. 2016-34. Passed 11-1-16.)
907.06  UNLAWFUL TREES AND SHRUBS.
   No person shall maintain or permit to stand, any tree or shrub designated
dead, diseased or deemed a menace to health, safety and welfare of the people
of Westerville.
(Ord. 73-36. Passed 6-19-73.)
907.07  PRUNING OBSTRUCTIONS.
   (a)   It shall be the duty of any person or persons owning or occupying real
estate bordering on any street upon which property there may be trees or shrubs
to prune such trees or shrubs in such manner that they will not obstruct or
shade the street lights, obstruct the passage of pedestrians on sidewalks,
obstruct vision of traffic signs, or obstruct the view of any street or alley
intersection. The minimum clearance of any overhang portion thereof shall be
ten feet over sidewalks, and twelve feet over all streets except truck
thoroughfares which shall have a clearance of sixteen feet.
   (b)   Should any person or persons owning real estate property bordering on
any street fail to prune trees or shrubs as herein provided, the City Manager
or designee shall order such person or persons within ten days after receipt of
written notice, to so prune such trees or shrubs.
   (c)   The order required herein shall be served by mailing a copy of the
order to the last known address of the property owner, by certified mail.
   (d)   When a person to whom an order is directed shall fail to comply within
the specified time, it shall be lawful for the City to prune such trees or
shrubs and the exact cost thereof shall be assessed to the owner as provided by
law in the case of special assessments.
(Ord. 73-36. Passed 6-19-73.)
907.08  ABUSE OR MUTILATION OF PUBLIC TREES.
   Unless specifically authorized by the City Manager or his designee, no
person shall intentionally damage, cut, carve, transplant or remove any tree or
shrub; attach any rope, wire, nails, advertising posters or other contrivance
to any tree or shrub; allow any gaseous liquid or solid substance which is
harmful to such trees or shrubs to come in contact with them; or set fire or
permit fire to burn when such fire or the heat thereof will injure any portion
of any tree or shrub.
(Ord. 73-36. Passed 6-19-73.)
907.09  PROTECTION OF TREES.
   (a)   All trees and shrubs on any street or other publicly owned property
near any excavation or construction of any building, structure or street work,
shall be guarded with a good substantial fence, frame or box, not less than
four feet high and eight feet square, or at a distance in feet from the tree or
shrub equal to the diameter of the trunk in inches at chest high, whichever is
greater, and all building material, dirt or other debris shall be kept outside
the barrier.
   (b)   No person shall excavate any ditches, tunnels, trenches or lay any
drive within a radius of ten feet from any public tree or shrub without first
obtaining a written permit from the City Manager or designee.
(Ord. 73-36. Passed 6-19-73.)
907.10  PLACING MATERIALS ON PUBLIC PROPERTY.
   No person shall deposit, place, store or maintain, upon any public place of
the City, any stone, brick, sand, concrete or other materials which may impede
the free passage of water, air or fertilizer to the roots of any tree growing
therein, except by written permission of the City Manager or his designee.
(Ord. 73-36. Passed 6-19-73.)
907.99  VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES.
   Any person, firm or corporation violating or failing to comply with any of
the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor.
(Ord. 73-36. Passed 6-19-73.)
CHAPTER 909
Sidewalks, Curbs and Gutters
909.01   Repairs generally; duty of abutting lot owners.
909.02   Notice.

   CROSS REFERENCES
   State law provisions - see Ohio R. C. Ch. 729
   Sidewalk offenses - see GEN. OFF.
Ch. 529
909.01  REPAIRS GENERALLY; DUTY OF ABUTTING LOT OWNERS.
   Each owner of any lot or parcel of ground in the City shall cause the
sidewalks, curbs and gutters and every part thereof in front of, along side or
abutting the lot or parcel to be kept in good repair and free from any
nuisance. Repairs shall be made by order of the City Manager and shall be
supervised by him or his authorized representative.
(Ord. 80-24. Passed 5-6-80.)
909.02  NOTICE.
   The City Manager is hereby authorized, ordered and directed to serve notice
on owners of land to repair all sidewalks, curbs or gutters or parts thereof,
abutting on such land, within not less than thirty days of the service of the
notice. Notice shall be served by certified mail addressed to the owner at his
last known address or to the address to which tax bills are sent or, if it
appears by the return of service that one or more of the owners cannot be
found, the owners shall be served by publication of the notice once in a
newspaper of general circulation within the Municipal corporation.
(Ord. 80-24. Passed 5-6-80.)
909.03  FAILURE TO COMPLY.
   If the owner of such land fails to comply with the notice or to cause the
repairs to be completed in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, the
City Manager shall cause the sidewalks, curbs or gutters, or parts thereof, to
be repaired and assess the costs thereof against the lots and lands abutting
thereon.
(Ord. 80-24. Passed 5-6-80.)
909.04  PERMIT REQUIRED; APPLICATION; FEE.
   No person shall repair or construct any sidewalk, curb or gutter, or a
portion thereof within the City without first obtaining a permit therefor.
Applications for permits shall be made in writing to the City Engineer. The fee
for such permit shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00), except that if not more
than three sections or not more than seventy-five square feet of sidewalk,
whichever is lesser, is to be constructed or repaired, or if not more than
fifteen linear feet of curb or gutter is to be constructed or repaired, the fee
shall be fifteen dollars ($15.00).
(Ord. 85-8. Passed 4-2-85.)
909.05  COMPLIANCE WITH SPECIFICATIONS.
   All construction and repair of sidewalks, curbs and gutters shall be in
accordance with the plans and specifications issued by the City Engineer.
(Ord. 80-24. Passed 5-6-80.)
909.06  BOND; DISCRETION OF CITY MANAGER.
   Persons making applications pursuant to Section
909.04 may be required to file a bond in a penal sum to be determined by the
City Manager or his authorized representative according to the nature of the
job to be done, such bond shall be conditioned to save the City harmless from
any injury to any person or property which may be caused by the construction or
repair.
(Ord. 80-24. Passed 5-6-80.)
909.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not
more than fifty dollars ($50.00). A separate offense shall be deemed committed
each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 80-24. Passed 5-6-80.)

931.02  LIEN FOR  CHARGES; USE OF FUNDS.
   (a)   Lien for Charges.  Charges accruing under the terms of Sections
931.01 to
931.04 shall constitute a lien upon the property served, and, if not paid may
be certified to the County Auditor for collection in the same manner as
property taxes.
   (b)   Use of Funds. Funds received from the sale of water shall be deposited
in a separate fund and used for the payment of the costs and expense of the
management, maintenance, operation, repair and extension of the water treatment
and distribution system, and for the payment of principal and interest on any
debt incurred in the construction of or replacements or additions to the water
treatment and distribution system.
(Ord. 00-81. Passed 12-5-00; Ord. 08-17.  Passed 7-8-08.)
931.03  SERVICE INSTALLATION.
   Persons, firms or corporations desiring a water service line installed from
an existing main to the property line shall file an application in writing with
the Building Department. The application shall set forth the size and location
of the service line required.
   The City shall charge such persons, firms or corporations the entire cost
for such service line installation. The cost determined by the Director of
Public Service must include all labor, materials and equipment plus 20%. The
cost shall be deposited in advance with the City and include the complete
rehabilitation of any lawn area, sidewalk and public or private street
disturbed by the installation of the service line required. The breakdown of
such cost shall be made available to the applicant upon request.
   The Director of Public Service shall schedule such installation to be made
no later than ten working days from the payment date unless delayed or
prohibited by emergency conditions.
   The installation of a service line and/or water meter made by persons, firms
or corporations other than the City shall be made in accordance with all
specifications of the City and subject to inspection and final approval by the
City. The City Engineer's office shall determine under what conditions a street
opening permit shall be granted and the specifications for sod, curb, sidewalk
and street replacement.
   The City Engineer or designee may also request that a cash bond be deposited
with the City in an amount sufficient to cover the rehabilitation of any
street, curb, sidewalk and/or lawn area within right of way which may be
deposited with the City prior to the beginning of any work. The City shall hold
such bond until all work is completed and accepted by the City.
   The charges for a water tap set forth in this section shall include all
necessary labor, equipment and material to deliver water to the property line
of the property to be served at a right angle to the water main, at a point
most convenient for locating the service box where it will be protected from
damage. The City shall repair and maintain the service line to and including
the service stop and service box, provided that the service line is of standard
copper, lead or cast iron construction. Maintenance and repair costs of a
service line which is not constructed of standard copper, lead or cast iron
shall be paid by the property owner.
   The property owner shall maintain the water line except as set forth herein.
   A change of location of the service stop or tap required by the property
owner, including driveway construction, shall be charged to the property owner.
(Ord. 00-81. Passed 12-5-00; Ord. 08-17.  Passed 7-8-08.)
931.04  METER INSTALLATION AND MAINTENANCE.
   (a)   Persons, firms or corporations requesting water service shall purchase
meters from the City. These meters shall be installed by the owner at the
owner’s expense.  Charges for meters shall be determined administratively by
the City Manager, with recommendations from the Finance Director and the Water
Utility Manager, based on applicable material, labor and overhead costs,
provided City Council, after first being provided at least ten (10) days
advance written notice, does not object.
   (b)   The water meter shall be installed before the water service is turned
on. If water is needed for construction before the water meter can be
installed, a fee of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) per month, or any part
thereof shall be charged. Notice of the use of construction water shall be
directed to the Director of Finance for the purpose of billing. The water meter
shall be installed in a safe and accessible location in a building, provided by
the property owner, unless otherwise authorized by the City Engineer, and the
location shall be subject to the approval of the City Manager or designee. The
location shall be as near the entrance of the water line into the building as
possible. The property owner shall install connections for the meter equal to
Ford or Mueller type copper-setters. Nothing shall be placed, built or stored
over or around the meter setting which will interfere with the accessibility of
the meter for reading. Clear access to the remote read box must also be
maintained. A change of the location of the meter shall be subject to the
approval of the City and the property owner shall pay the cost and expense of
moving the meter. No person, other than a City employee or authorized
representative, shall connect, disconnect or in any manner tamper with, adjust
or service any water meter.
   (c)   In the construction of all new structures which require the
installation of a water meter and outside remote meter reading device, the City
shall supply and install a cable to the device. If the Chief Building Official
determines that the remote reading device cable must be installed in a conduit,
the owner shall install the conduit as directed by the Chief Building Official.
   (1)   The owner shall install a shutoff valve at the meter on the City side
of the meter.
   (2)   The City shall provide normal maintenance and servicing of the meter
without cost to the owner. Damage to the meter caused by freezing or hot water,
by the negligence of any person other than a City employee or representative
shall be paid by the owner. The owner shall pay the cost and expense of
restoration of service, meter readings other than regularly scheduled readings,
meter testing and such other services that are not performed by the City
employees or representatives in the course of normal meter service. Service
charges shall be based on time and materials plus 20%.
   (d)   No person other than a City employee or representative shall operate a
valve to any main line or service line. Any person other than a City employee
or representative operating a valve shall be deemed guilty of a third degree
misdemeanor.
   (e)   Water used by an owner, developer or other person in charge of
chlorination and other preparation of main lines and appurtenances thereto as
well as water used for hydraulic testing of sewers or other uses of water in a
subdivision, prior to acceptance by the City, shall be charged to that owner,
developer or other person. The amount of water used shall be determined either
by the Director of Public Service, or by a meter, which can be requested of the
Water Utility Manager by the developer, owner or person in charge prior to
seven days preceding the need for its use. The use of a meter is subject to the
provisions of subsection (f) hereof.
   (f)   Hydrant meters may be used for any short term use of water subject to
the following regulations:
      (1)   An applicant for a hydrant meter shall deposit the sum of five
hundred dollars ($500.00) for a three inch meter and two hundred and fifty
dollars ($250.00) for a 3/4 inch meter by check or money order payable to the
City of Westerville. The deposit shall be held by the City to secure return of
the meter and payment for use of water. Upon return of the meter, the deposit
will be returned to the applicant after deduction of unpaid water use charges,
late return charges and any charge for damage to the meter or equipment.
      (2)   Water use shall be charged at the rates established in Section
931.01. The minimum charge for each hydrant meter per month, or any part
thereof, shall be twenty five dollars ($25.00).
      (3)   The use of a hydrant meter shall be limited to time periods
established by the Water Utility Manager. A charge of ten dollars ($10.00) per
day may be assessed for the late return of a meter.
      (4)   The Water Utility Manager shall promulgate rules for issuing
hydrant meters and charges for use for related equipment.
   (g)   Maintenance and repair of pipes and water hydrants and appurtenances
thereto prior to final acceptance by the City, shall be the responsibility of
the developer and owner.
(Ord. 00-81. Passed 12-5-00; Ord. 08-17.  Passed 7-8-08.)
931.05  DELINQUENT BILLS AND CHARGES FOR RESTORING SERVICE.
   Charges accruing under the terms of Section
931.01 shall be billed monthly, on a date or dates and for such usage periods
as may be determined by the City Department of Finance.  Bills shall be due and
payable on the date stated within, which shall not be less than fifteen days
from the day the bill is sent. If not paid by the due date, the bill will be
considered past due. When two consecutive bills are past due, the water service
is subject to termination for nonpayment.
   Water service that has been terminated for nonpayment shall be assessed a
turn-on charge that must be paid prior to service restoration. The turn-on
charge shall be determined administratively by the Finance Director based on
labor costs plus twenty percent (20%).
   Whenever the restoration of service, for reasons other than nonpayment, is
made outside of regular working hours the charge therefor shall be the actual
labor cost plus twenty percent.
(Ord. 00-81. Passed 12-5-00; Ord. 2016-40. Passed 12-6-16.)
931.06  WATER SYSTEMS CAPACITY CHARGE.
   (a)   Definitions.  As used in this section:
      (1)   “Service connection” means the connection of all or any part of a
water service line to a tap.
      (2)   “Tap” means the connection to a water main and the necessary pipes
or lines extending from a water main to and including the curb stop or valve
and box.
   (b)   Rates.  The following rates shall be charged for each water service
connection made to any property and shall be paid at the time a permit is
issued for the water connection.  No person shall make a water service
connection or any part thereof, unless a permit has been issued therefor by the
Building Inspector.  In the event that a tap is subsequently enlarged, the
difference between the current charges for the two tap sizes shall be paid:
 
Diameter of Tap (in inches) Rate For Connection
0.75  $2,900.00
1.00  4,850.00
1.50  10,500.00
2.00  22,915.00
3.00  49,845.00
4.00  78,500.00
6.00  170,645.00
8.00  268,920.00
10.00 363,040.00
12.00 435,650.00
16.00 686,150.00
 
   For any taps used to supply fire protection only, the rate shall be one-half
the rate specified in this section.
   (c)   Master Meter. Notwithstanding the rates set forth in division (b), if
the City Manager determines:
      (1)   That a development will consist of multiple buildings, each of
which contains either commercial uses or contains no less than four dwelling
units (“development”); and
      (2)   That based on sound engineering principals, multiple buildings in
the development can be served and master-metered by one (1) tap of sufficient
size, (“the master meter tap”); and
      (3)   That the “rate for connection” for all taps which would serve each
building of the Development exceeds the applicable “rate for connection” for
the master meter tap,
   then the City Manager is authorized to adjust and modify the “rate for
connection,” for the development provided that in no event shall such charge be
less than the “rate for connection” for the master meter tap.
   (d)   Use of Money. The funds received from the collection of such charges
shall be deposited daily with the Director of Finance who shall credit them to
the Water Revenue Fund from which Council may make appropriations for the
payment of the cost and expense of the construction, management and repair of
the water distribution system, water reservoir towers and other water system
improvements and extensions and for the payment of principal and interest on
any debt incurred for the construction of such water distribution system, water
reservoir towers and other water system improvements and extensions.
(Ord. 00-81. Passed 12-5-00; Ord. 09-46.  Passed 11-3-09; Ord. 2018-27.  Passed
11-13-18.)
931.07  LAWN WATERING RESTRICTIONS; SHORTAGES AND EMERGENCY RESTRICTIONS.
   (a)   The City Manager is hereby authorized and directed to declare a water
emergency at any time that there is insufficient or inadequate water supply or
pressure to provide safe and adequate water within the City. Examples of
situations which create such an emergency include, but are not limited to the
following:
      (1)   A water main break;
      (2)   Any physical or mechanical failure at the Water Treatment Plant;
      (3)   Dry or drought conditions; or
      (4)   Restriction of water supply by state or federal authorities.
   (b)   During a water emergency, nonessential uses of water including, but
not limited to, the following may be restricted as provided in this section:
      (1)   Watering lawns;
      (2)   The commercial and residential use of water to wash boats, cars,
trucks and other vehicles;
      (3)   Filling swimming pools:
      (4)   Watering from hydrants;
      (5)   Washing sidewalks, driveways, porches and building exteriors;
      (6)   The sterilization, blowoff and testing of water lines and sewer
mains;
      (7)   The burning of paper, trash, wood or other combustible material.
   (c)   Upon declaration of and during the existence of a water emergency, the
City Manager is hereby authorized and directed to determine which nonessential
uses of water shall be restricted or prohibited. Such declaration shall be made
public by publication therein in a newspaper of general circulation in the
City, by posting notice at the Municipal Building and by giving notice to local
media. The City Manager is authorized and directed to establish rules and
regulations regarding prohibited water usage, water restrictions, and for the
reduction or termination of water service during any declared water emergency.
   (d)   No domestic or commercial user or any other person shall violate any
emergency restriction or prohibition imposed pursuant to this section.
(Ord. 00-81. Passed 12-5-00; Ord. 2018-27.  Passed 11-13-18.)
931.08  PRIVATE LINES; REIMBURSEMENT OF CONSTRUCTION COSTS.
   (a)    For the purpose of this chapter:
      (1)    "Private water line" means a water line, not less than six inches
in diameter, connecting with the water distribution system of the City, the
construction of which is financed entirely or in part with other than public
funds and which is designed to provide local service for property abutting the
water line or which may in the future abut an extension thereof.
      (2)    "Owner" means the person who owns such private water line at the
time of the acceptance of such water line by the City.
   (b)    Within sixty days from the time of completion of the construction of
such water line, the owner thereof shall file with the City Manager a statement
setting forth the entire cost of such water line to the owner, describing that
part of abutting property which may connect to the water line and setting forth
the amount of the cost for each such property.
   (c)    Such private water lines may be extended by the City or the City may
authorize others to extend the same to serve property not abutting the water
line as built.
   (d)    Water service for any abutting property may be connected to such
water line if, in the opinion of the City Manager, such connection with
reference to the best interest of the City and the water distribution system of
the City can or should be made. The person desiring to make such connection
shall pay into the City treasury the sum determined by the City Manager as just
and equitable to both parties, which amount so determined shall be binding upon
both parties. Such sum shall be held by the City, subject to the demand of the
owner, or his heirs or assigns, for a period of six years after the date of
collection. At the expiration of the six years, if the sum has not been claimed
by the owner or his heirs or assigns, it shall then and thereafter be the
property of the City and shall be credited to the General Fund.
   However, such sum paid to the City for connection to such private water line
shall become the sole property of the City and shall be credited to the General
Fund when such property is situated as follows:
      (1)    Abutting an improved street at the time of the passage of this
section (Ordinance 1081, passed December 4, 1956)
      (2)    Having available water facilities, other than such private water
line, at the time of the passage of this section (Ordinance 1081, passed
December 4, 1956).
      (3)    Abutting upon an improved street in which water facilities, other
than such private water line, have been installed at the time of the connection
to such private water line.
   (e)    Upon the completion of the private water line, the owner shall
dedicate such water line to the City, subject to its acceptance, following
which acceptance the City shall be responsible for all maintenance and repair.
   (f)    The owner of such private water line shall make no assignment of any
or all of his or its rights or obligations thereto without the consent of the
City.
   (g)    The City Manager shall prepare and maintain a permanent record of
costs, abutting properties and payments for connections to private water lines.
(Ord. 00-81.  Passed 12-5-00.)
931.09  CHARGES WHERE NO PREVIOUS ASSESSMENT HAS BEEN PAID.
   (a)    For the purpose of providing revenue to help finance and to equitably
distribute the cost of construction of water lines, it is hereby determined and
declared necessary to establish, exact and regulate charges for water lines
where these facilities are used by owners of property who cannot show that a
special assessment was paid for the construction of such or similar water
lines. Such charges shall be in addition to other fees which may be exacted
with respect to such water lines.
   (b)    The City Manager is hereby authorized and directed to set and exact
such charges for water lines upon the granting of permission to connect such
property to such water line. Such charges shall be set and exacted on a foot
frontage or benefit basis and shall be based upon similar water installation
charges incurred by the City on projects completed within the two years
immediately preceding such permission to connect. In the event that there have
been no similar installations within such two-year period, such charges shall
be set by the City Manager, subject to the approval of Council. 
(Ord. 00-81.  Passed 12-5-00.)
931.10  TAMPERING WITH WATER HYDRANTS, PIPES OR METERS; UNAUTHORIZED
CONNECTIONS.
   (a)    No person shall open, close, adjust or interfere with a water
hydrant, valve, regulator, gauge, gate, disc, curb cock, stopcock, meter or
other regulator, operating or measuring device or appliance in or attached to
the wells, tanks, reservoirs, conduits, pipes, mains, service pipes, house
pipes or other pipes or apparatus of the City or furnisher of water, with
intent to cause the escape of water or to injure or destroy such property. No
person shall tap, sever, open or make unauthorized connections with a main or
pipe used or intended for the transmission of water. This section does not
apply to the agent or employee for that purpose, of the owner or operator of
the appliances referred to in this section, and does not apply to anything done
by or under authority of the Fire Department.
   (b)    All restrictions contained in subsection (a) hereof shall apply to
water hydrants on private property. Additionally, these hydrants shall only be
used for fire protection and control and the City maintains the right to
inspect these hydrants at any time.
(Ord. 00-81.  Passed 12-5-00.)
931.11  BACKFLOW PREVENTION AND CROSS-CONNECTION CONTROL.
   Pursuant to
Article III, Section 13(g) of the City Charter there is hereby adopted, for the
purpose of preventing backflow and providing cross-connection control in the
public water system, Rules 3745-95-03 through 3745-95-08 of the Ohio
Environmental Protection Agency Rules and Regulations for Public Water Systems,
as were effective on November 26, 1980, and Rules 3745-95-01, 02, 04 through 07
of the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency Rules and Regulations for Public
Water Systems, as were effective on May 1, 2003,  save and except that
"Director" as defined in Rule 3745-95-01(K) and "Supplier of Water" as defined
in Rule 3745-95-01(AA) shall mean the Director of Public Utilities as provided
in
Article V, Section 6 of the City Charter and, further provided that "Public
Water System" as defined in Rule 3745-95-01(V) shall mean the City Public Water
System.
   Water Service that has been terminated for not conforming to the backflow
rules shall be assessed a turn-on charge by the Finance Director based on labor
costs plus twenty percent (20%) to cover administration and overhead costs. 
(Ord. 04-23.  Passed 7-6-04.)
931.12  YARD HYDRANTS; WATER CONTAMINANT LEVELS.
   Pursuant to
Article III, Section 13(g) of the City Charter, there is hereby adopted for the
purpose of restricting the flow of ground water from yard hydrants into the
water supply and for the purpose of regulating the maximum microbiological
contaminant level of water supply systems, Rules 3745-81-14, 3745-81-21 and
3745-99-01 of the Ohio Administrative Code, as were effective on November 26,
1980, except that "Director" as used in Section 3745-81-21 shall mean the
Director of Public Utilities as provided in
Article V, Section 5 of the City Charter.
(Ord. 00-81.  Passed 12-5-00.)
931.13  ACCESS TO WATER METERING SYSTEMS.
   (a)    The Director of Public Utilities is hereby authorized to install,
read and maintain metering systems to any and all properties served with water
or sewer by the City.
   (b)    The Director of Public Utilities or appointed agents are authorized
to enter all properties served with water and/or sewer by the City for the
purpose of installing, reading and maintaining the metering system.
   (c)    Water service may be terminated for failure of a customer to provide
access to the property for the purpose of installing, reading or maintaining
the metering systems, after being given notice and a reasonable time in which
to comply with such notice.
   (d)    The customer shall pay the appropriate service termination and
resumption charges as specified in this chapter for denying access to the
Director of Public Utilities or his agents for the purpose of installing,
reading and maintaining the metering system.
(Ord. 00-81.  Passed 12-5-00.)
931.14  WATER SYSTEM CONNECTIONS REQUIRED.
   (a)    Every person owning or having control of any dwelling house or
structure containing a water system shall provide for the connection of such
water system with the public water system, where the same is accessible, within
six months from the date of accessibility of the public water system;
providing, however, that when land which is used for single-family residential
purposes is annexed to the City, the dwelling house located on such land at the
time of annexation shall be connected to the public water system, when such
system is accessible, within five years from the date of the approval of the
annexation by the Council, or within six months from the date of accessibility
of the system, whichever is later, provided further, that connection shall be
made at an earlier date if the on-site water system creates a health hazard or
upon the change of use of the real estate to a use other than a single-family
residence.
   (b)    Whenever a public water system is located not more than 300 feet from
a dwelling or other structure, such water system shall be deemed accessible
under the terms of this section.
(Ord. 00-81.  Passed 12-5-00.)
931.99  PENALTY.
   In addition to any remedies provided for herein, whoever violates any
provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars
($500.00).
(Ord. 00-81.  Passed 12-5-00.)

CHAPTER 935
Sewers
   EDITOR'S NOTE: Ordinance 1536, passed August 15, 1967, as amended by
Ordinance 76-22, passed March 16, 1976, authorized the City Manager to execute
a contract with the City of Columbus, providing for the discharge of sewage,
industrial wastes, water and other liquid wastes from the City of Westerville
into the sewerage system and sewage treatment works of the City of Columbus and
for the transportation, pumping and treatment of such wastes.

935.01  SANITARY SEWER CONNECTIONS REQUIRED.
   (a)    Every person owning or having control of any dwelling house or
structure containing a sanitary sewer system shall provide for the connection
of such sanitary sewer system with the public sanitary sewer system, where the
same is accessible, within six months from the date of accessibility of the
public sanitary sewer system; providing, however, that when land which is used
for single-family residential purposes is annexed to the City, the dwelling
house located on such land at the time of annexation shall be connected to the
public sanitary sewer system, when such system is accessible, within five years
from the date of the approval of the annexation by the Council, or within six
months from the date of accessibility of the system, whichever is later,
provided further, that connection shall be made at an earlier date if the on-
site sanitary sewer system creates a health hazard or upon the change of use of
the real estate to a use other than a single-family residence.
   (b)   Whenever a public sanitary sewer system is located not more than 300
feet from a dwelling house or other structure, such sanitary sewer system shall
be deemed accessible under the terms of this section.
(Ord. 84-27.  Passed 9-4-84.)
935.02  SEWER SYSTEM CAPACITY CHARGES.
   (a)   For the purpose of providing funds to help finance and to more
equitably distribute the cost of construction of necessary additions to the
sewerage system, it is hereby determined and declared to be necessary to
provide for the establishment, exaction and regulation of a sanitary sewerage
system capacity and connection charge, as hereinafter determined, such charges
to be an addition to any and all other fees which may be imposed with respect
to the City sewerage system.
   (b)   The funds received from the collection of such charges shall be
deposited daily with the Director of Finance who shall credit them to the Sewer
Revenue Fund from which Council may make appropriations for the payment of the
cost and expense of the engineering, construction, management and repair of the
sanitary sewerage system, regulator chambers, storm standby tanks and pumping
stations and for the payment of the cost and expense of replacement, extensions
to or enlargement of the same and for the payment of principal and interest on
any debt incurred for the construction of such sewerage system, regulator
chambers, storm standby tanks and pumping stations.
   (c)   A sanitary sewerage system capacity charge shall be exacted whenever:
      (1)   Application is made for the issuance of a sewer permit to provide
sanitary sewer service to a new structure; and
      (2)   An existing structure is enlarged or its use changed, which
necessitates a larger water tap.
   (d)   The charge exacted pursuant to subsection (c) hereof shall be
determined in accordance with the following:
 
Diameter of Tap (in inches) System Capacity Fee

1.00  8,324

3.00  61,822

8.00  329,000
10.00 511,000
12.00 721,800
16.00 801,000
 
   Credit for any existing structure which has a use charge or for an existing
structure which is enlarged or removed may be applied against the system
capacity charge herein imposed in the amount of the original structure charge
up to, but not more than, the current charge. 
(Ord. 05-42.  Passed 12-6-05.)
935.03  TRUNK SEWER CHARGES.
   (a)   The Building Inspector is hereby authorized and directed to exact a
sanitary sewerage system connection charge whenever application is made for the
issuance of a sewer permit to provide connection to the sanitary sewerage
system for service to a structure, wherever such property is or will be
tributary, directly or indirectly, to any trunk sanitary sewer either inside or
outside the corporate limits of the City.
   (b)   The charge so exacted shall be determined in accordance with the
following:
      (1)   For each single-family dwelling unit to which connection is needed,
the charge shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00).
      (2)   For each family unit in any multi-dwelling structure to which
connection is needed, the charge shall be seventy-five dollars ($75.00).
(Ord. 1790.  Passed 8-22-72.)
935.04  RATES.
   (a)   Charges.  The following rates are fixed and established as the fair,
proportional and reasonable charges for sewer service and use calculated upon
the meter consumption of water with the rate based upon 100 cubic feet
intervals as follows:
 
Minimum monthly charge which includes first 200 cu. $19.98
ft.
Over 200 cubic feet per month                       $6.05 per 100 cubic feet
 
   (b)   Unmetered Water Discharged Into Sewerage System.  In the event that
unmetered water is discharged into the City sanitary sewers, the user shall
install a City approved meter on the sewer connection line and such user shall
pay the City for the metered sewage at the rates prescribed by the City and the
cost and expense of the meter and the installation thereof shall be paid by the
user.
   (c)   Collection of Sewer Service Charge.  The sewer service charge shall be
billed monthly, on a date or dates and for such usage periods as may be
determined by the City Department of Finance and shall be shown as a separate
item upon the City utility bills.  Bills shall be due and payable on the date
stated within, which shall not be less than fifteen days from the day the bill
is sent.
   (d)   Lien for Charges.  Charges accruing under the terms of this section
may constitute a lien upon the property served, and, if not paid within ninety
days, may be certified to the County Auditor for collection in the same manner
as property taxes.
   (e)   Use of Moneys.  Moneys received from the use of sanitary sewers shall
be deposited in the Sewer Revenue Fund and used for the payment of the costs
and expense of sewage treatment and the cost of the management, maintenance,
operation and repair of the sewerage system.  Any accumulated surplus in such
fund may be used for the payment of additions or replacements, or for the
payment of principal and interest on any debt incurred in the construction or
replacement of or addition to the sewerage system or for the extension of the
sewage system to serve unsewered areas.
(Ord. 07-52.  Passed 12-11-07; Ord. 08-40.  Passed 12-2-08; Ord. 09-57.  Passed
12-15-09; Ord. 2010-61.  Passed 12-7-10; Ord. 2011-51.  Passed 12-6-11; Ord.
2012-33.  Passed 11-13-12; Ord. 2013-40. Passed 12-3-13; Ord. 2014-35. Passed
12-2-14; Ord. 2015-42. Passed 12-1-15; Ord. 2016- 40. Passed 12-6-16.)
935.041  DEDUCT WATER METERS.
   The Building Department may permit the installation of auxiliary water
meters that are installed in such a manner as to determine the quantity of
water not actually entering the sanitary sewer system.  In such cases, the
quantity of water used to determine the sanitary sewer charge shall be
calculated by deducting the recorded water usage that does not enter the
sanitary sewer from the recorded water usage from the main water meter.
   Auxiliary water meters shall be purchased from the City and shall be
installed by the owner at the owner’s expense.  The Building Department shall
promulgate rules and regulations for the installation of such auxiliary water
meters and the payment of fees and expenses for the meters.
   The City shall provide normal maintenance of the meters without cost, during
the manufacturer’s warranty period, after which it shall be the owner’s
responsibility.  Damage to the meter caused by freezing or hot water, or by
negligence of any person other than a City employee or representative, shall be
paid for by the owner.  The owner shall pay the cost and expense of restoration
of service, meter testing and any other services performed by City employees or
representatives outside the scope of normal meter service.  Service charges
shall be based on time and material plus 20%.
   A deduct meter fee of $2.00 per meter shall be charged for each billing
period to recover administrative and operational costs associated with the
meter.  The fee shall become effective January 1, 2005. 
(Ord. 04-22.  Passed 7-6-04.)
935.05  PRIVATE LINES; REIMBURSEMENT OF CONSTRUCTION COSTS.
   (a)   For the purpose of this section:
      (1)   “Private sewer” means a sewer, other than a house sewer, not less
than eight inches in diameter, connecting with and discharging directly into
the sewerage system of the City, or indirectly into such system, through an
authorized extension thereof, the constructon of which is financed entirely or
in part with other than public funds and which is designed to provide local
service for property abutting the sewer or which may in the future abut an
extension thereof.
      (2)    "Owner" means the person who owns such private sewer at the time
of the acceptance of such sewer by the City.
   (b)    Within sixty days from the time of completion of the construction of
such private sewer, the owner thereof shall file with the City Manager a
statement setting forth the entire cost of such sewer to the owner, describing
that part of abutting property which may connect to the sewer and setting forth
the amount of the cost for each such property.
   (c)    Such private sewers may be extended by the City or the City may
authorize others to extend the same to serve property not abutting the sewer as
built.
   (d)    House sewers for any abutting property may be connected to such
private sewer if, in the opinion of the City Manager, such connection with
reference to the best interest of the City and the sewerage system of the City
can or should be made. The person desiring to make such connection shall pay
into the City treasury the sum determined by the City Manager as just and
equitable to both parties, which amount so determined shall be binding upon
both parties. Such sum shall be held by the City, subject to the demand of the
owner, his heirs or assigns, for a period of six years after the date of
collection. At the expiration of the six years, if the sum has not been claimed
by the owner or his heirs or assigns, it shall then and thereafter be the
property of the City and shall be credited to the General Fund. However, such
sum paid to the City for connection to such private sewer shall become the sole
property of the City and shall be credited to the General Fund when such
property is situated as follows:
      (1)    Abutting an improved street at the time of the passage of this
section (Ordinance 1081, passed December 4, 1956).
      (2)    Having available sewer facilities, other than such private sewer,
at the time of the passage of this section (Ordinance 1081, passed December 4,
1956).
      (3)    Abutting upon an improved street in which sewer facilities, other
than such private sewer, have been installed at the time of the connection to
such private sewer.
   (e)    Upon the completion of the private sewer, the owner shall dedicate
such sewer to the City, subject to its acceptance, following which acceptance
the City shall be responsible for all maintenance and repair.
   (f)    The owner of such private sewer shall make no assignment of any or
all of his or its rights or obligations thereto without the consent of the
City.
   (g)    The City Manager shall prepare and maintain a permanent record of
costs, abutting properties and payments for connections to private sewers.
(Ord. 1081. Passed 12-4-56.)
935.06  CHARGES WHERE NO PREVIOUS ASSESSMENT PAID.
   (a)    For the purpose of providing revenue to help finance and to equitably
distribute the cost of construction of sanitary sewers, it is hereby determined
and declared necessary to establish, exact and regulate charges for sanitary
sewers where these facilities are used by owners of property who cannot show
that a special assessment was paid for the construction of such or similar
sanitary sewers. Such charges shall be in addition to other fees which may be
exacted with respect to such sanitary sewers.
   (b)    The City Manager is hereby authorized and directed to set and exact
such charges for sanitary sewers upon the granting of permission to connect
such property to such sanitary sewer. Such charges shall be set and exacted on
a foot frontage or benefit basis and shall be based upon similar sewer
installation charges incurred by the City on projects completed within the two
years immediately preceding such permission to connect. ln the event that there
have been no similar installations within such two-year period, such charges
shall be set by the City Manager, subject to the approval of Council.
(Ord. 1102. Passed 4-16-57.)
935.07  PROHIBITED DISCHARGES.
   (a)    No person shall permit or cause the discharge of storm water, roof
water, surface and subsurface drainage or other clean waste water into the
sanitary sewers of the City.
(Ord. 1147. Passed 8-12-58.)
   (b)    No user of the sanitary sewers of the City shall introduce into the
sewer system any sewage or wastes of such a nature as to be detrimental or
harmful to the effective treatment and disposal of sewage and wastes in
accordance with accepted standards.
(Ord. 1272. Passed 2-20-62.)
935.08  INSPECTIONS.
   The Director of Public Service or other officer designated by Council shall
have authority to enter upon any land and into any buildings which have been
heretofore or may be hereafter connected directly or indirectly with the
sanitary sewer for the purpose of inspecting the use and purpose of such
connections.
(Ord. 188. Passed 4-20-06.)
935.09  SEWER SERVICE AND USER CHARGE ADJUSTMENT.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Former Section 935.09 was repealed by Ordinance 83-7, passed
February 15, 1983.)
935.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provisions of this chapter or order of the Director of
Public Utilities pursuant to this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor of the first degree and fined an amount not to exceed one thousand
dollars ($1,000) or imprisonment for not more than six months, or both. Each
day or portion thereof during which a violation occurs shall be considered a
separate offense.
(Ord. 91-23. Passed 4-16-91.)
CHAPTER 936
Discharges Into Sewers
936.01   Definitions.
936.02   Purpose.
936.03   Prohibited discharges.
