935.07
936.01  DEFINITIONS.
   Whenever they are used in this chapter, the meaning of the following terms
shall be as defined in this section:
   (a)    "Approved laboratory procedures" means the measurements, tests and
analyses of the characteristics of water and wastes in accordance with
analytical procedures determined acceptable by Federal Guidelines as
established in Title 40, Code of Federal Regulations, Part 136, or as approved
by the Regional Director, U. S. Environmental Protection Agency.
   (b)    "Biodegradable" means that the material shall be easily amendable to
breakdown to less complex compounds by biologic processes present in the City's
sewerage system. The Director of Public Utilities shall determine whether a
material is biodegradable, if such determination is required.
   (c)    "Building drain" means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a
building drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste and
other building drainage piping and conveys it to the building sewer.
   (d)    "Combined sewer" means a sewer which was designed to carry both
sanitary sewage, industrial wastewaters and surface water runoff.
   (e)    "Cooling water" means the unpolluted wastewater discharged from any
system of heat transfer such as condensation, air conditioning, cooling or
refrigeration.
   (f)    "Department" means the Westerville Department of Public Utilities.
   (g)    "Incompatible" means that the waste material is harmful or interferes
with wastewater treatment processes, or that there is no substantial removal by
treatment processes, or that the presence of the material affects the quality
of the wastewater treatment plant effluent.
   (h)    "Industrial cost recover charge" means that charge assessed on an
industrial user to recover that portion of Federal grant amounts allowable to
the treatment of the wastewater of such user.
   (i)    "mg/L" means milligrams per liter.
   (j)    "Natural outlet" means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch,
lake or other body of surface water.
   (k)    “Oils and greases” means those materials extractable from an
acidified sample by "freon" or other acceptable solvent in accordance with
accepted laboratory procedures.
   (l)    "Organic" means containing carbon compounds or produced by living
organisms.
   (m)    "Public sewer" means any sewer owned by the City, including storm,
sanitary or combined sewers.
   (n)    "pH" means the logarithm to the base 10 of the reciprocal of the
concentration of the hydrogen ion in grams per liter of solution.
   (o)    "Pretreatment" means the treatment of industrial wastewaters prior to
introduction into public sewerage facilities.
   (p)    "Sanitary sewage" means sewage containing water-carried wastes
contributed from premises by reason of human occupancy.
   (q)    "Sanitary sewer" means a sewer which carries sanitary sewage and
industrial wastes and to which storm, surface and ground waters are not
intentionally admitted.
   (r)    "Sewerage system" means all of the facilities required to transport
sewage from the premises of the source to a sewage treatment facility and the
treatment and disposal facility. All such facilities of the City and entities
contributing to the City facilities shall be considered one such sewerage
system.
   (s)    "Sewer service charge" means the total charge to a sewer system user
and may include user charges for operation and maintenance, surcharges, special
fees, industrial cost recovery charges and other appropriate charges.
   (t)    "Storm sewer" means a sewer which carries surface water runoff and
drainage and is not intended to carry sanitary sewage, industrial wastes or
other polluted wastewaters.
   (u)    "Toxic" means capable of affecting any organism adversely upon
assimilation or exposure.
   (v)    "Wastewater" means a combination of liquid and water carried wastes.
(Ord. 76-11. Passed 3-11-76.)
   (w)    "NPDES (National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System) permit"
means the same as such is defined in the Code of Federal Regulations, 40 CFR
Part 125, and in Public Law 92-500, Section 402.
   (x)    "Compatible pollutant" means biochemical oxygen demand, suspended
solids or any other pollutant that the publicly-owned treatment works was
designated to treat and in fact does remove such pollutants to a substantial
degree.
   (y)    "Normal domestic wastewater" means sewage which when analyzed shows
by weight a daily average of not more than 250 parts per million of suspended
solids and not more than 200 parts per million of BOD.
   (z)    "BOD" (denoting biochemical oxygen demand) means the quantity of
oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter, under standard
laboratory procedure, in five days at twenty degrees centigrade, expressed in
parts per million by weight.
   (aa)    "Suspended solids" means solids that either float on the surface of,
or are in suspension in, water, sewage or other liquids, and which are
removable by laboratory filtering.
   (bb)    "Industrial wastes" means the liquid waste from industrial
manufacturing processes, trade or business as distinct from sanitary
wastewater.
   (cc)    "Sanitary wastes" means waterborne wastes from residences, business
buildings, institutions and industrial establishments contributed by reason of
human occupancy and discharged from sanitary plumbing facilities.
(Ord. 77-24. Passed 5-3-77.)
936.02  PURPOSE.
   The provisions of this chapter are established because it is necessary to
regulate the discharge of unacceptable materials into the sewerage system in
order to prevent damage to sewerage system facilities and processes.
(Ord. 76-11. Passed 3-11-76.)
936.03  PROHIBITED DISCHARGES.
   (a)    No person shall discharge to a public sewer any materials deleterious
to any part of the City's sewerage system, treatment process or sludge disposal
operation. Such deleterious materials or substances shall include, but not
necessarily be limited to:
      (1)    Any solid or viscous substance capable of causing obstruction to
the flow in sewers or other interference with the proper operation of the
sewerage system, i.e., construction materiels, ashes, cinders, sand, mud,
straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastic, wood, fur, wax.
      (2)    Flammable or explosive substances such as gasoline, kerosene,
benzene, naphtha or other substance capable of causing flammable or explosive
conditions.
      (3)    Any liquid or vapor that would cause the sewage temperature in the
public sewer to be higher than 100°F. (38° Celsius).
      (4)    Any water or wastes, acid or alkaline in reaction, and having
corrosive properties capable of causing damage or hazard to structures,
equipment or personnel of the Department. The acidic or alkaline character of
such wastes must be neutralized at all times to within the permissible range of
pH, which range is between 5.0 and 12.0.
      (5)    Any water or waste containing readily releasable cyanide (cyanide
released at a temperature of 150° F (66° C. ) and pH = 2. 5) in excess of 2 mg/
L; any water or waste containing total cyanide in excess of 5 mg/L.
      (6)    Any water or waste containing over 200 mg/L of readily
biodegradable oils and greases which may become solid or viscous within the
sewerage system, or over 25 mg/L of mineral or other nondegradable oils and
greases, regardless of physical characteristics.
      (7)    Any liquids or wastes containing toxic or poisonous substances in
sufficient quantities or rate of flow as to injure or interfere with any of the
sewage treatment process, to constitute a hazard to human beings or animals, or
to create any hazard in the receiving waters. Limits for such materials may be
established by the Director of Public Utilities.
   (b)    No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged to any natural
outlet or storm sewer any sanitary sewage or other polluted wastewaters.
(Ord. 76-11. Passed 3-16-76.)
936.04  DETERMINATION OF ACCEPTABILITY OR UNACCEPTABILITY OF DISCHARGE.
   The Director of Public Utilities shall determine the acceptability or
unacceptability of all questionable discharges to the sewerage system. Such a
determination shall be made on a basis of sound engineering and operational
evaluations taking into consideration the nature and concentration of the
discharge, its point of entry into the sewerage system, its compatibility with
other discharges in the system, its compatibility with the treatment facility
receiving it, and all other factors pertinent to the effect of the discharge on
any part of the system or treatment process.
(Ord. 76-11. Passed 3-16-76.)
936.05  DISCHARGE OF CERTAIN MATERIALS PERMITTED CONDITIONALLY.
   (a)    Certain toxic substances and pathogenic bacteria, the admission into
the system which would otherwise be prohibited, shall be acceptable in a
discharge if,
      (1)    Reduced by treatment at the source to a point that will meet the
general purposes of these rules and regulations or come within any applicable
standards set thereon now or hereafter in accordance with this chapter; or
      (2)    Discharged in such small concentrations and quantities so as to
not be injurious to personnel; sewers; any biochemical, biological or other
sewage treatment process; or receiving waters.
   (b)    Such substances include, but are not necessarily limited to:
      (1)    Any alcohols, antibiotics, arsenic, arsenicals, bromine, iodine,
chlorine, copper, copper salts, cresols, creosotes, fluorine, formaldehydes,
mercury, mercuricals, phenols, phenol derivatives, silver, silver compounds,
silvermides, toxic dyes (organic and mineral) or zinc;
      (2)    Any strong oxidizing agents such as chromates, dichromates,
permanganates or peroxides;
      (3)    Any chemical compounds producing toxic, flammable or explosive
gases either upon acidification, alkalization, oxidation or reduction;
      (4)    Any strong reducing agents such as nitrates, sulphides, sulfites
and thiosulphates;
      (5)    Any waste from industrial processes, hospital procedures or
commercial processes containing viable pathogenic organisms.
(Ord. 76-11. Passed 3-16-76.)
936.06  LIMITS ON STRENGTH OF TOXIC AND DELETERIOUS SUBSTANCES.
   No person shall discharge wastewater containing toxic or deleterious
substances or materials in excess of the following listed concentrations:
 
Substance or Material Allowable Discharge mg/L
Arsenic                  0.5
Barium                   8.0
Cadmium                  0.3
Chromium    - Hexavala1.0
      - Total      6.0
Copper                   0.5
Iron                     50.0
Lead                     0.5
Manganese                5.0
Mercury                  0.01
Nickel                   10.0
Selenium                 0.1
Silver                   0.05
Zinc                     2.0
Chloride                 1000
Phenol                   1.0
 
   These limitations are not intended to supersede any more stringent
regulations that may be established by State or Federal regulatory agencies.
(Ord. 76-11. Passed 3-16-76.)
936.07  UNACCEPTABLE DISCHARGES.
   Unacceptable discharges include those which have been determined by the
Director of Public Utilities to:
   (a)    Contain materials or substances which would constitute a hazard to
life and limb  of personnel engaged in inspection, maintenance, and operation
of the system. 
   (b)    Contain materials or substances which are toxic as defined by this
chapter.
   (c)    Contain materials or substances which are in any way deleterious to
any part of  the system.
   (d)    Contain concentrations of any toxic or deleterious materials or
substances in  excess of any limits set thereon in accordance with this
chapter.
   (e)    Cause the City to incur excessive expense in the handling or
treatment thereof.
   (f)    Be incompatible with the treatment process or inhibit the performance
of the treatment process at a City treatment facility.
   (g)    Be of such volume or contain such organic or other material load
which would cause the treatment facility to exceed its design capabilities.
   (h)    Cause a treatment facility to fail to meet effluent requirements set
by State and Federal regulatory agencies or cause such effluent to have a
degrading effect on the receiving body of water.
   (i)    Cause the wastewater treatment system's effluent or any other product
of the treatment process such as residues, sludges or scums, to be unsuitable
for reclamation and reuse or to interfere with the reclamation process.
   (j)    Cause a nuisance or prevention of the effective maintenance or
operation of the wastewater treatment system through having a strong,
unpleasant odor.
   (k)    Cause air pollution by the release of toxic or malodorous gases or
malodorous gas producing substances.
(Ord. 76-11. Passed 3-16-76.)
936.08  UNACCEPTABLE DISCHARGES: ALTERNATE PROCEDURES.
   Upon determination that an existing or proposed wastewater discharge is
unacceptable, the Director of Public Utilities may:
   (a)    Refuse wastewater treatment service to the person discharging or
proposing to discharge unacceptable waste and may order the removal of such
discharges from the sewerage system, including the physical removal of
connection to the system; or,
   (b)    Require provision of pretreatment of the wastewater by equipment and
procedures to assure that wastewater discharges to the sewerage system will at
all times be acceptable; and/or,
   (c)    Require payment to compensate for added costs of handling, treating
and disposing of the wastes which are not recovered by service charges or
industrial cost recovery charges.
(Ord. 76-11. Passed 3-16-76.)
936.09  UNACCEPTABLE DISCHARGES: PRETREATMENT PROGRAM.
   Upon notification by the Director of Public Utilities that pretreatment of
wastewater discharges is required the person responsible for such discharge
shall:
   (a)    Submit to the Director, within seven calendar days of notification, a
proposal for a scheduled program to implement the installation of pretreatment
equipment and/or procedures. Such program shall describe steps to be taken to
provide pretreatment and the anticipated schedule of implementation of each
step.
(Ord. 76-11. Passed 3-16-76.)
      Such pretreatment shall be done in accordance with Federal Regulations 40
CFR 128, "Pretreatment Standards."
(Ord. 77-24. Passed 5-3-77.)
   (b)    Upon acceptance of the scheduled program by the Director, the person
responsible shall proceed to implement the program in accordance  with the
proposal as accepted. Such person shall notify the Director at monthly
intervals as to his progress in implementing the program. The Director may
order removal of the unacceptable wastewater discharge from the sewerage system
at any time during pretreatment program implementation if unsatisfactory
progress is evident or if necessary to protect the sewerage system from damage.
(Ord. 76-11. Passed 3-16-76.)
936.10  UNACCEPTABLE DISCHARGES: OPERATION OF PRETREATMENT FACILITIES.
   Wastewater pretreatment or control facilities shall be maintained
continuously in satisfactory and effective operation and shall be subject to
periodic inspection. The person responsible shall maintain operating records as
required by the Director of Public Utilities and shall submit reports of the
character of the influent and effluent to show the performance of the
pretreatment or control facilities as required by the Director.
(Ord. 76-11. Passed 3-16-76.)
936.11  UNACCEPTABLE DISCHARGES: PRETREATMENT FACILITIES PLAN APPROVAL.
   Detail plans, specifications and sufficient design information to allow
proper evaluation of proposed pretreatment facilities shall be submitted for
approval prior to construction. Such approval by the Director of Public
Utilities shall signify that best engineering judgment indicates that the
proposed facilities will be capable of providing satisfactory pretreatment.
Such approval does not, in any way, guarantee that the facilities will function
satisfactorily, or that it will not be necessary to enlarge or otherwise modify
the facilities to make them capable of providing satisfactory pretreatment. It
remains the owner’s responsibility to assure compliance with all discharge
limitations.
(Ord. 76-11. Passed 3-16-76.)
936.12  PROHIBITIONS ON STORM DRAINAGE AND GROUND WATER.
   Storm water and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged into such
sewers as are specifically designed and designated as storm or combined sewers.
   Storm water, ground water, rain water, roof runoff, street drainage,
subsurface drainage or yard drainage shall not be discharged through direct or
indirect connections to a sanitary sewer. Any such connections shall be
considered illegal and shall be subject to immediate removal by the owner of
the premise so connected and at such owner's expense.
   No person constructing a sanitary sewer, building or house connection, shall
leave same open, unsealed or incomplete in such fashion as to permit storm,
surface or subsurface water to enter the sewer system.
(Ord. 76-11. Passed 3-16-76. )
936.13  DISCHARGE OF UNPOLLUTED WASTEWATERS.
   Unpolluted wastewater, including but not limited to cooling and process
waters, shall be discharged to storm sewers or natural outlets where available.
Discharge of unpolluted wastewaters to sanitary sewers shall be prohibited,
unless specifically authorized by the Director of Public Utilities for good
cause.
(Ord. 76-11. Passed 3-16-76.)
936.14  MONITORING AND FLOW MEASUREMENT FACILITIES.
   Installation of wastewater monitoring and/or flow measurement facilities may
be required of any industrial user upon notification of necessity for
installation of such facilities by the Director of Public Utilities. The
purpose of such facilities shall be to allow inspection, sampling and flow
measurement of wastewater discharges. Plans for proposed monitoring and flow
measurement facilities shall be submitted for approval to the Director of
Public Utilities within sixty days of receipt of request for installation by
the user and installation shall be completed within ninety days of approval by
the Director.
   Monitoring facilities and/or flow measurement facilities required shall be
constructed, operated and maintained at the user's expense. The entire facility
and its equipment shall be maintained at all times in a safe and proper
operating condition by the user. Access to the monitoring and/or flow
measurement facilities shall be made available immediately to authorized
representatives of the Department of Public Utilities at any time that
wastewater discharge may be expected to take place. The authorized
representatives of the Department of Public Utilities shall have the right to
set up and operate monitoring equipment at the facilities.
   The monitoring facility shall be located on the user's premises and shall be
so located as to be readily accessible at all times. It shall not be subject to
being obstructed by parked vehicles, supplies or equipment.
(Ord. 76-11. Passed 3-16-76.)
936.15  DISCHARGE REPORTS.
   The Department of Public Utilities may require any person discharging or
proposing to discharge wastewater into the sewerage system to file discharge
reports. The discharge reports may include but not be limited to nature of
process, volume, rates of flow, production quantities or other information that
relates to the generation of waste including substances and concentrations in
the wastewater discharge. Such reports may also include the chemical
constituents and quantity of liquid or gaseous materials stored on site even
though they may not normally be discharged. Discharge reports may be required
at intervals adequate to define changes in wastewater discharge
characteristics. In addition to discharge reports, the Department may require
information in the form of permit applications and self-monitoring reports.
(Ord. 76-11. Passed 3-16-76.)
936.16  INFORMATION NOT CONFIDENTIAL.
   All information and data on a user obtained from reports, questionnaires,
permit applications, permits and monitoring programs and from inspections shall
be available to the public without restriction.
(Ord. 76-11. Passed 3-16-76.)
936.17  PROTECTION FROM ACCIDENTAL DISCHARGE.
   Each user shall provide protection from accidental discharge to the sewerage
system of prohibited or other wastes regulated by this chapter. Such required
protection shall include walls or dikes, separate storage, removal of drain
lines from locations where significant quantities of prohibited materials are
maintained, or other appropriate procedures to assure the prevention of
discharge to the City sewerage system.
   Plans for installation of such control facilities or operating procedures
shall be submitted to the Director of Public Utilities for approval prior to
construction or at the time such control facilities are found to be necessary
by either the user or the Director of Public Utilities. The review and approval
of such plans and operating procedures shall not relieve the user of
responsibility for preventing the discharge of unacceptable materials to the
City sewerage system. 
   Users shall notify the Department immediately upon accidental loss of
prohibited materials or those unacceptable for discharge to enable
countermeasures to be taken to minimize damage to the wastewater treatment
system and/or the receiving waters. Such notification will not relieve users of
liability for any consequential expense, loss or damage to the wastewater
treatment system or for any fines and/or penalties imposed on the Department
which result from the violative discharge. 
(Ord.76-11. Passed 3-16-76.) 
936.18  CHARGES FOR DAMAGES TO SYSTEM. 
   When a discharge of wastes by any user causes an obstruction of, or damage
or any other impairment to, any part of the sewerage system, a charge shall be
levied by the Department against the user for the cost of the work required to
clear and/or repair the part of the system affected by such discharge. The
Department shall add such charge to the user's usual service charges,
surcharges and fees. 
(Ord. 76-11. Passed 3-16-76.) 
936.19  MALICIOUS DESTRUCTION OF PROPERTY. 
   No unauthorized person shall maliciously, willfully or negligently break,
damage, destroy, deface, cover or tamper with any wastewater treatment works
which is a part of the wastewater treatment system under the management of the
Director of Public Utilities. Any person violating this provision shall be
subject to immediate arrest under the charge of disorderly conduct. 
(Ord. 76-11. Passed 3-16-76.) 
936.20  ACCEPTANCE OF WASTE OF UNUSUAL STRENGTH OR CHARACTER.
   The City has the right to accept, from any person or industry, waste of
unusual strength or character subject to the provision set forth in this
chapter and the rates set forth in
Chapter 935 and subject to the sewer use regulations of the City of Columbus.
(Ord. 77-24. Passed 5-3-77.) 
936.21  APPLICATION, ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT OF COLUMBUS SEWER USAGE
ORDINANCES. 
   So long as the City discharges its sewage, industrial waste, water and other
liquid waste into the transportation, pumping and treatment system of the City
of Columbus, all of the provisions of Chapter 1145 and 1147 of the Columbus
City Code, both as they exist and as they are hereafter amended, relating to
the regulation of sewage use are hereby adopted by reference and made
applicable to the City sewerage system. In the event of conflict between the
provisions of this chapter and Chapters 1145 and 1147 of the Columbus City
Code, the provisions of Chapter 1145 and 1147 of the Columbus City Code shall
prevail. Officers and employees of the City of Columbus are hereby empowered to
enforce such provisions of the Columbus City Code within the boundaries of the
City.
(Ord. 87-57. Passed 10-6-87.) 
936.99  PENALTY. 
   Whoever violates any provisions of this chapter or order of the Director of
Public Utilities pursuant to this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor of the first degree and fined an amount not to exceed one thousand
dollars ($1,000) or imprisonment for not more than six months or both. Each day
or portion thereof during which a violation occurs shall be considered a
separate offense. 
(Ord. 91-23. Passed 4-16-91.)
CHAPTER 939
Electricity
939.01   Definitions.
939.02   General provisions.
939.03   Charges applicable to all rate classes.
939.04   Rate classes.
939.05   Security lights.
939.06   Maximum demand reduction for off-peak use institutions.
939.07   Net metering.
939.08   AMI opt out fee.
939.09   Subsidized or reduced rates.
939.10   Renewable energy purchasing program.
939.97   Mutual aid agreements.
939.98   Prohibitions.
939.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Power to establish electric light and power rates - see Ohio R.C. 715.03,
715.06
   Power to furnish light, power and heat - see Ohio R.C.715.06, 717.01
939.01  DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   “Billing Month.” The period of time, not to exceed 34 days, which is
determined and may be adjusted by the Director of Finance, in consultation with
the Electric Utility Manager.
   (b)   “Customer.” A person (natural or artificial) who obtains electric
service from the City of Westerville Electric Division.
   (c)   “Customer Charge.” A fixed monthly fee charged to a customer for each
meter to have electric service available at that meter. This charge is incurred
regardless of whether energy is used. The customer charge for each rate class
shall be set forth in the Table of Rates (Electric) as adopted by Council.
   (d)   “Energy Charge.” A charge assessed based upon on a customer’s metered
electricity usage, during a billing month as measured in kilowatt-hours (kWh).
The energy charge for each rate class shall be set forth in the Table of Rates
(Electric) as adopted by Council.
   (e)   “Energy Charge (Winter Discounted).” A discounted charge permitted on
the portion of a residential service customer’s energy usage that exceeds
800kWh during the calendar months of October through May, unless modified by
the Electric Utility Manager in the terms and conditions. This charge shall
only be permitted on the portion of energy that exceeds 800 kWh in an
applicable billing month.
   (f)   “General Service.” Any electrical service to a customer that does not
qualify as residential service.
   (g)   “Maximum Demand.” The maximum demand shall be measured in kilowatts
(kW), and shall be determined as the highest thirty minute integrated kW demand
recording of an integrating demand meter.
   (h)   “Maximum Demand Charge.” A charge levied upon on a customer’s maximum
demand in a billing month. If a customer has more than one meter, the maximum
demand charge shall be calculated using the sum of the maximum demands of each
meter. The maximum demand charge for each rate class shall be set forth in the
Table of Rates (Electric) as adopted by Council.
   (i)   “Maximum Reactive Demand.” The maximum reactive demand shall be
measured in kilovars (kVar), and shall be determined as the highest thirty
minute integrated kilovolt-ampere reactive demand recording of an integrating
demand meter.
   (j)   “Maximum Reactive Demand Charge.” A charge that levied based upon on a
customer’s maximum reactive demand in a billing month. If a customer has more
than one meter, the maximum reactive demand charge shall be calculated using
the sum of the maximum reactive demands of each meter. The maximum reactive
demand charge for each rate class shall be set forth in the Table of Rates
(Electric) as adopted by Council.
   (k)   “Minimum Monthly Demand Charge.” A charge levied upon a customer each
month, regardless of demand usage. The minimum monthly demand charge shall be
the greater of the following:
      (1)   Fifty percent (50%) of the highest maximum demand registered during
the preceding twelve billing months;
      (2)   The amount as specified in a written service contract between the
Westerville Electric Division and the customer;
      (3)   The minimum monthly demand charge for each rate class as set forth
in the Table of Rates (Electric) adopted by Council.
   (l)   “Power Supply Cost Adjustment Charge (PSCA).” A charge applicable to
all energy usage levied pursuant to this Chapter to reflect increases or
decreases in wholesale power supply costs, including but not limited to,
purchased energy, capacity, transmission, and ancillary services, provided such
will include only power supply pass through costs. The PSCA charge shall be
established by the City Manager in accordance with Section
939.03 (c) hereof.
   (m)   “Primary Power.” Electrical transformation and distribution facilities
that are owned and maintained at the customer’s own cost and which have been
approved by the City.
   (n)   “Residential Service.” Electrical service provided to a single meter
which services a single dwelling unit that is intended to be occupied solely as
a residence. For purposes of this Chapter, dwelling unit shall carry the same
meaning as set forth in Part Eleven (Planning and Zoning Code) of the Codified
Ordinances of Westerville, Ohio, as may be amended.
   (o)   “School.” An institution whose primary use of electrical service is
for the operation of a public or private educational facility that offers any
combination of first through twelfth grade education, and that does not operate
at substantial capacity for a significant period of time during July and
August.
   (p)   “Table of Rates (Electric).” The Table of Rates (Electric) shall be
adopted by Council. All references to the Table of Rates (Electric) in this
Chapter shall refer to the most recently-adopted version, which shall be on
file with the Clerk of Council.
(Ord. 2016-18.  Passed 7-5-16; Ord. 2017-20.  Passed 12-5-17; Ord. 2018-26. 
Passed 11-13-18.)
939.02  GENERAL PROVISIONS.
   (a)   Terms and Conditions of Service.
      (1)   The City Manager, in consulting with the Electric Utility Manager,
is authorized to promulgate and amend terms and conditions for the provision of
electric service, which are hereby incorporated by reference, as if fully
rewritten herein, as they may be amended. Such terms and conditions may
include, but need not be limited to: availability of rates, service
connections, meters, meter testing, deposits, billing, payment due dates and
methods, nonpayment, disconnection of service and service charges, and the
nature and substance of electric contracts.
      (2)   By accepting electric service from the City of Westerville the
customer agrees to the City’s terms and conditions of service. A copy of the
terms and conditions of service will be made available upon request.
   (b)   Billing. Customers shall be sent a bill not less frequently than once
per billing month, on a date or dates and for such usage periods as may be
determined by the City of Westerville Department of Finance. Bills shall be due
and payable from customers on the date stated therein, which shall not be less
than 15 days from the day the bill is sent to the customer.
   (c)   Length of Term. If multiple rate classes are available for a
customer’s premises, the customer may choose from among the available rate
classes, provided that a customer may not switch rate classes less than 12
months from that customer’s most recent rate class change.
   (d)   Corrections to Billing.
      (1)   If the City has undercharged a customer for electricity service
because of a malfunctioning metering system or billing error, the Department of
Finance may bill the customer for the estimated unbilled electricity
consumption used in the two-year period immediately prior to the date the City
remedies the malfunctioning meter or billing error.
      (2)   If, however, during the two-year period described in Section (d)
(1), the City has attempted to verify or repair a malfunctioning metering
system or billing error and the customer has not responded to requests to read
or repair the meter or verify information, the Department of Finance may bill
the customer for the estimated amount of the unbilled electricity used in the
six-year period immediately prior to the date the City remedies the
malfunctioning meter or billing error.
      (3)   This section does not apply to tampering with utility equipment or
theft of utility service as defined in Section
939.98 or R.C. §§ 4933.18 and 4933.19, or where a physical act of a customer or
its agent causes inaccurate or no recording of the meter reading, inaccurate or
no measurement of the electricity rendered, or inaccurate or no billing of
services actually provided.
(Ord. 2016-18.  Passed 7-5-16; Ord. 2017-20.  Passed 12-5-17.)
939.03  CHARGES APPLICABLE TO ALL RATE CLASSES.
   Customers shall pay the following charges in an amount as set forth in the
Table of Rates (Electric) as set by Council:
   (a)   Customer Charge. A customer charge is due each month regardless of
whether energy charge is incurred in that month. The customer charge for each
rate class shall be set forth in the Table of Rates (Electric) as adopted by
Council.
   (b)   Energy Charge. The energy charge shall be levied for each rate class,
and shall be the rate set forth the Table of Rates (Electric) as adopted by
Council.
   (c)   Power Supply Cost Adjustment Charge. In addition to the energy charge
rates established by council, each customer shall pay a power supply cost
adjustment charge (PSCA). The PSCA shall be applied to all kilowatt-hours sold
under all rate classes provided herein, to reflect increases or decreases in
wholesale power supply costs, including but not limited to, purchased energy,
capacity, transmission, and ancillary services. The PSCA shall be calculated
periodically based on wholesale power supply cost data from the most recent
six-month period preceding the start of the billing month to which the PSCA is
to be applied. PSCA revisions calculated in accordance with this section shall
be established by the City Manager, and shall not require approval of City
Council unless the PSCA exceeds the limit set by Council in the Table of Rates
(Electric), in which case such approval may be provided by motion of City
Council. Revised PSCA rates shall take effect in the next billing month after
the calculated six- month period and shall be prorated for partial billing
month customers.
(Ord. 2016-18.  Passed 7-5-16.)
939.04  RATE CLASSES.
   The following are hereby fixed as the classes available for the sale of
electrical energy from the municipal electric system of the City for light and
power purposes to its customers and not for resale:
   (a)   Schedule R: Residential Service.
      (1)   Availability. Available for residential service through one meter
to an individual customer. Rates are applicable to each separately-metered
service.
      (2)   Energy Charge (Winter Discounted). Customers on residential service
who have service in excess of 800 kwh may be billed at the energy charge
(winter discounted) for applicable usage. This charge shall only be permitted
on the portion of energy that exceeds 800 kWh in an applicable billing month.
      (3)   Equal Monthly Payments. The City Manager may promulgate rules and
regulations permitting residential service customers to pay all charges in
substantially equal estimated monthly payments, provided that each customer
shall annually pay in full the total energy charges computed under the terms of
this section. This payment option shall not be available to any other rate
class.
   (b)   Schedule GSS: General Service, Small.
      (1)   Availability. Available for all customers in general service. This
class is intended for non-residential general service customers whose maximum
demand is generally less than 50 kilowatts (kW) per billing month.
      (2)   Applicable Charges. In addition to all charges set forth in Section
939.03  of this Chapter, customers in this rate class shall be subject to the
following charges:
         A.   Maximum Demand Charge.
   (c)   Schedule GSL: General Service Large.
      (1)   Availability. Available for all customers in general service. This
class is intended for non-residential general service customers whose maximum
demand is generally greater than 50 kilowatts (kW) per billing month, and who
do not have primary power.
      (2)   Applicable charges. In addition to all charges set forth in Section
939.03 , customers in this rate class shall be subject to the following
charges:
         A.   Minimum Monthly Demand Charge.
         B.   Maximum Demand Charge.
         C.   Reactive Demand Charge.
         The maximum demand charge in this rate class shall only be assessed
upon the amount of maximum demand that exceeds 50kW in any billing month.
      (3)   Metering. Electricity usage for this rate class shall be measured
on the low side of any applicable transformer.
      (4)   School Exemption. Should a customer operating a school elect to be
billed in this rate class, the customer shall be exempt from paying the minimum
monthly demand charge.
   (d)   Schedule GSL-PP: General Service Large - Primary Power.
      (1)   Availability. Available for all customers in general service who
have primary power facilities. This class is intended for general service
customers whose maximum demand is generally greater than 50 kilowatts (kW) per
billing month, and who do have primary power facilities.
      (2)   Applicable Charges. In addition to all charges set forth in Section
939.03  of this Chapter, customers in this rate class shall be subject to the
following charges:
         A.   Minimum Monthly Demand Charge.
         B.   Demand Charge.
         C.   Reactive Demand Charge.
      (3)   Metering. Electricity usage for this rate class shall be measured
on the high side of any applicable transformer.
   (e)   Schedule GSL - Schools: General Service Large - Schools.
      (1)   Availability. Available to schools that do not have primary power
facilities.
      (2)   Applicable Charges. In addition to all charges set forth in Section
939.03  of this Chapter, customers in this rate class shall be subject to the
following charges:
         A.   Demand Charge.
         B.   Reactive Demand Charge.
      (3)   Metering. Electricity usage for this rate class shall be measured
on the low side of any applicable transformer.
   (f)   Schedule GSL - Schools - PP: General Service Large - Schools, Primary
Power.
      (1)   Availability.  Available to schools that have primary power
facilities.
      (2)   Applicable Charges. In addition to all charges set forth in Section
939.03  of this Chapter, customers in this rate class shall be subject to the
following charges:
         A.   Demand Charge.
         B.   Reactive Demand Charge.
         C.   Minimum Monthly Demand Charge.
      (3)   Metering. Electricity usage for this rate class shall be measured
on the high side of any applicable transformer.
   (g)   Schedule GST: General Service Transmission.
      (1)   Availability. Available for general light and power service for
other than residential use, supplied through the City’s 69 kV transmission
facilities for customers having a minimum demand of more than 1,500 kilovolt-
amperes at a single location and meter.
      (2)   Metered Voltage. Energy charges for GST customers are based upon
delivery and measurement of energy at the same voltage; thus measurement will
be made at or compensated at the delivery voltage. Determination of the
measurement voltage shall be at the sole discretion of the City. Measurements
taken at the low-side of a customer-owned transformer shall be multiplied by
1.01.
      (3)   Determination of Demand. The demand shall be the maximum thirty
minute integrated kilovolt-ampere demand recording of an integrating demand
meter. The demand in any month shall not be less than 1,500 kVA or the minimum
billing demand, if any, as may be specified in the service contract, or
otherwise established by the Electric Utility Manager.
      (4)   Service and Contract Provisions. Prior to service being rendered
hereunder, the customer may enter into a written service contract which shall
specify, among other provisions, the electricity and capacity requirements of
the customer, pre- and post-term contract ratchet charges if any, termination
and notice requirements, curtailment conditions in the case of emergencies,
deposit and payment provisions, and minimum monthly payment requirements,
connection and construction charges, provisions regarding metering, term of
contract, load requirements, and default provisions. Each separate point of
delivery of service by one or more metered services shall be considered a
contract location and shall be metered and billed under a separate service
contract.
      (5)   One Metered Service per Location. Only one metered service of each
type, as to voltage and phase, will be supplied to a customer under this
schedule at one contract location. Where two or more services are supplied to a
customer at one contract location, the services, within the limitations above
stated, may be serviced under separate contracts under this or other applicable
schedules, at the customer’s option.
      (6)   Term of Contract. The term of the contract for service under this
schedule shall be as provided in the individual contract with each customer,
but in no case shall the contract term be for less than one year.
(Ord. 2016-18.  Passed 7-5-16.)
939.05  SECURITY LIGHTS.
   (a)   Definition. A “security light” is an exterior light that, with the
City’s consent, is directly connected to electrical service without passing
through a meter.
   (b)   Charges, Contracts. Charges for security lights shall be levied per
light, shall be levied on a monthly basis and shall include installation and
maintenance (including lamp replacement) at the city’s expense. All contracts
for installation and maintenance of security lights shall be for a three-year
period. Rates for security lights shall be levied on customers in amounts and
classifications to be determined by Council in the Table of Rates (Electric).
   (c)   Residential, Commercial. Residential security lights are defined as
those lights up to and including 250 watt high pressure sodium equivalent
lights. Commercial security lights are defined as those lights in excess of 250
watt high pressure sodium equivalent lights.
   (d)   Poles. A light without a City pole is a light affixed to a previously-
existing pole or structure, either of which is maintained by the customer at
the customer’s expense. Where the City additionally provides a pole, it shall
install a thirty-five-foot pole, and also provide up to 150 feet of aluminum #6
duplex wire. If additional wire is required, a per-foot charge based on current
market value will be made.
(Ord. 2016-18.  Passed 7-5-16.)
939.06  MAXIMUM DEMAND REDUCTION FOR OFF-PEAK USE INSTITUTIONS.
   General service customers who operate institutions whose primary use of
electrical service is for the conducting of public services and related
activities that result in maximum demand occurring during off-peak hours may
request to receive a 35% reduction on the applicable maximum demand charge. The
Electric Utility Manager shall respond to all such requests in accordance with
the terms and conditions promulgated pursuant to Section 939.02(a). Off-peak
hours shall be defined as all of the hours of Saturdays, Sundays, New Year’s
Day, Presidents Day, Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving
Day and Christmas Day, and the hours between 9:00 p.m. of each day and 7:00
a.m. of the following day for all days.
(Ord. 2016-18.  Passed 7-5-16.)
939.07  NET METERING.
   (a)   Availability of Service. This option is available to customers in all
rate classes who own and operate qualifying generator facilities designed to
operate in parallel with the City’s system. Customers served with this option
must also take service under an applicable rate class set forth in Section
939.04 .
   (b)   Conditions of Service.
      (1)   A qualifying generator facility is one that meets all of the
following:
         A.   Is a generator that may be fueled by a fuel, or by solar, wind,
biomass, landfill gas, or hydropower, or uses a microturbine, a battery, or a
fuel cell;
         B.   Is owned and operated by the customer and is located on the
customer’s premises;
         C.   Is designed and installed to operate in parallel with the city’s
system without adversely affecting the operation of equipment and service of
the City and its customers and without presenting safety hazards to City; and
         D.   Is installed in accordance with the manufacturer’s specifications
as well as all applicable provisions of the National Electrical Code; and
         E.   Complies with all applicable safety and performance standards
established by the National Electrical Code, the Institute of Electrical and
Electronic Engineers, and Underwriters Laboratories;
         F.   Is intended primarily to serve or offset part or all of the
customer’s electricity needs; and
         G.   Is compliant with all applicable zoning and building ordinances,
regulations, and approvals, including screening, sheltering, maintenance, and
operation.
      (2)   To apply for the net metering option, the customer or the
customer’s authorized representative shall submit a letter with the customer’s
name and address and all of the following information regarding the customer’s
generator facility: Inverter type, size, certification, and manufacturer’s
specifications including details about circuit protective devices; generation
facility certifications; the installing electrician name, address, and phone
number; and proof of inspection and approval from the appropriate City
inspector(s).
      (3)   The Electric Utility Manager may require customers to sign an
interconnection agreement before a customer can participate in net metering.
   (c)   Metering. Metering shall be accomplished using a single meter capable
of registering the flow of electricity in each direction. If the existing
electrical meter installed at the customer’s facility is not capable of
measuring the flow of electricity in two directions, the customer shall be
responsible for all expenses for the purchase and installation of an
appropriate meter with such capability. The City may, at the customer’s
expense, require the installation of one or more additional meters to monitor
the flow of electricity.
   (d)   Net Energy. A customer’s net energy shall be calculated by subtracting
the kwh of electricity the customer’s generator facility feeds back to the
city’s system during a billing month from the customer’s metered usage of
electricity supplied by the city.
   (e)   Monthly energy charges. Monthly energy charges shall be determined
according to the applicable rate class.
      (1)   If a customer’s net energy is positive during a billing month, all
energy charges of the customer’s applicable rate class shall be calculated
using the customer’s net energy usage for the billing month. All other charges
shall be applicable and charged as set forth the Table of Rates (Electric) and
calculated in accordance therewith.
      (2)   If a Customer’s net energy is negative during a billing month, only
the energy charge of the customer’s standard service Schedule shall be
calculated using the customer’s net energy supplied to the City. All other
charges shall be applicable and charged as set forth in the Table of Rates
(Electric) and calculated in accordance therewith. If the customer’s net
billing under the standard service schedule is negative during the billing
month, the negative net billing shall be allowed to accumulate as a credit to
offset energy charges the customer incurs in future billing months. After eight
consecutive billing months of accumulated credit, the customer may request a
refund.
   (f)   Additional Charges. The customer shall pay any additional charges
applicable to the customer’s rate class, including but not limited to maximum
demand charge and maximum reactive demand charge based on energy delivered to
the customer, and any charges for equipment, labor, metering, testing or
inspections requested by the customer.
(Ord. 2016-18.  Passed 7-5-16.)
939.08  AMI OPT OUT FEE.
   This Section is reserved for future use.
(Ord. 2016-18.  Passed 7-5-16.)
939.09  SUBSIDIZED OR REDUCED RATES.
   This Section is reserved for future use.
(Ord. 2016-18.  Passed 7-5-16.)
939.10  RENEWABLE ENERGY PURCHASING PROGRAM.
   (a)   Definitions.
      (1)   "Renewable Energy" shall mean electric energy generated from
environmentally-friendly, renewable sources, including but not limited to,
wind, hydroelectric, solar, biomass, and landfill gas.
      (2)   "Renewable Energy Purchasing" shall mean the City's purchase and
retirement of Renewable Energy Certificates or REC(s) based upon an enrolled
Customer's participating percentage of metered electricity usage (measured in
kWh or MWh) during a reporting period.
      (3)   "Renewable Energy Purchasing Program" means a program where
Customers may voluntarily enroll to have the City complete Renewable Energy
Purchasing on the Customer's behalf, and to be assessed a charge therefor.
   (b)   Availability. Upon application, and based upon availability, Customers
in all rate classes may voluntarily enroll in a Renewable Energy Purchasing
Program. A Customer may select a participation percentage of twenty-five
percent, fifty percent, seventy-five percent, or 100 percent of their metered
electricity usage to be subjected to the applicable charge.
   (c)   Applicable Charges. The applicable charge for Customers who are
enrolled in the Renewable Energy Purchasing Program shall be in amount(s) set
forth in the Table of Rates (Electric), attached to Ordinance 2018-04 as
Exhibit A and incorporated herein by reference.
(Ord. 2018-04.  Passed 3-20-18.)
939.97  MUTUAL AID AGREEMENTS.
   (a)   The City Manager is hereby authorized and directed to enter into
mutual aid contracts with various municipal, rural, or investor-owned-electric
systems electric systems within or outside of the State of Ohio for emergency
repair service and for emergency equipment, personnel and supplies in case of
emergencies, and to approve invoices for same.
   (b)   Such mutual aid agreements shall contain terms which provide as
follows:
      (1)   In the event of an emergency each party may request, in writing,
aid from the other in the form of additional manpower and/or equipment.
      (2)   Each such request for aid shall specify, to the extent practicable,
the assistance required and an estimate of the length of time such assistance
may be needed.
      (3)   Each responding community need only respond to the extent
consistent with the proper operation of its own electrical system.
      (4)   The community rendering aid shall be reimbursed by the community
requesting such aid as follows:
         A.   A charge for labor equal to the actual cost for the total number
of man-hours expended rendering aid, including travel time, by employees of the
aiding community. Employee fringe benefit costs shall be determined by using a
factor of two times the total cost of the labor charge.
         B.   A materials and supplies charge equal to the actual cost of fuel,
materials and supplies expended, rendering such aid, including fuel expenses
incurred in traveling to and from the site of such aid.
         C.   The actual cost of that loss or damage to the equipment of the
aiding community, not recovered from insurance.
      (5)   Payment for such aid, determined in accordance with subsection (b)
(4) hereof, shall be rendered upon presentation of an invoice detailing the
same, or within thirty days.
      (6)   Personnel of the aiding community shall be considered acting within
the scope of their employment, to the same extent as if they were performing
their regular duties, while engaged in such aid.
      (7)   Under no circumstances shall the responding party or its employees
so responding, be liable to the requesting party, its inhabitants or others,
for any damages arising in any way as a result of the rendering of such aid or
the failure to respond to a call for such aid.
      (8)   Under no circumstances shall the party requesting such aid be
liable to the party responding, its inhabitants, or others, for any damages
arising in any way from the response to such a request for aid or the rendering
thereof, except as outlined in subsection (b)(4)C. hereof.
      (9)   Each contract shall be in effect for a one-year period, with a
provision for automatic renewal unless canceled by a thirty-day notice.
(Ord. 2016-18.  Passed 7-5-16.)
939.98  PROHIBITIONS.
   No person shall:
   (a)   Take or in any way use electricity which is furnished by the City for
private use, unless such person has first received a permit for such use from
the Westerville Electric Division.
   (b)   Deface, damage, molest or obstruct in any manner, any building,
machinery, wiring apparatus or other fixture or appliance of the Westerville
Electric Division.
   (c)   Make any attachment, addition to, or alteration in any City service
wires, or any fixture or appliance connected with the service, unless the
person first procures a permit from the Building Inspector for such work and
makes a written return of the same fully showing all such connections and
extensions, together with such other data as may be required by the rules and
regulations of the Westerville Electric Division.
   (d)   After making any connection with a service line, or after making
repairs or putting in any new attachments, allow the current to enter the
premises without first obtaining permission from the Electric Utility Manager.
   (e)   Tap or make any connection with any circuit or distributing wires of
the City without a properly authorized employee of the Westerville Electric
Division acting under the direction of the Electric Utility Manager.
(Ord. 2016-18.  Passed 7-5-16.)
939.99  PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates Subsections (a) or (d) of Section
939.98 of this Chapter shall be guilty of Theft under
Chapter 513 of the Codified Ordinances of Westerville, Ohio or similar state
statute.
   (b)   Whoever violates Subsections (b) or (c) of Section
939.98 of this Chapter shall be guilty of Criminal Damaging or Endangering
under
Chapter 509 of the Codified Ordinances of Westerville, Ohio or similar state
statute. The violation shall include a rebuttable presumption that such act
created a risk of physical harm as described in
Chapter 509.
   (c)   Whoever violates Subsection (e) of Section
939.98 of this Chapter shall be guilty of Disrupting Public Services under
Chapter 2909 of the Ohio Revised Code or similar statute or ordinance. The
violation shall include a rebuttable presumption that such act interrupted or
impaired power or other utility services to the public as described in Chapter
2909.
   (d)   Whoever violates any other provisions of this Chapter for which a
penalty is not set forth above, or violates any of the Terms and Conditions of
Service promulgated pursuant to Section
939.02 of this Chapter, shall be fined not more than two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00). A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on
which a violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 2016-18.  Passed 7-5-16.)

CHAPTER 945
Placement of Underground Utilities
945.01   Underground facilities required.
945.02   Exceptions to requirement of underground utility facilities.
945.03   Variance and modifications.
945.04   Maintenance.
 
945.99   Penalty.
945.01  UNDERGROUND FACILITIES REQUIRED.
   (a)   All new utility facilities to be constructed within the City and
within any subdivision as such is defined in Section
1201.02, shall be placed underground within dedicated utility easements or
streets, alleys, properties and rights of way of the City.
   (b)   As used herein "utility facility" means all equipment and
appurtenances above or below ground in streets, alleys, utility easements,
properties and rights of way of the City, used or useful in supplying electric,
communication, television signal services, gas, sanitary, storm or any other
public or private utility.
(Ord. 93-20.  Passed 6-1-93.)
945.02  EXCEPTIONS TO REQUIREMENT OF UNDERGROUND UTILITY FACILITIES.
   The following aboveground utility facilities are permitted:
   (a)   Poles used exclusively for police and fire alarm boxes, traffic
control facilities or any similar municipal equipment installed under the
supervision and to the satisfaction of the Director of Public Service.
   (b)   Street lighting systems and lighting units comprised of poles,
standards, luminaires, conductors and appurtenant equipment for street lighting
systems and for area lighting.
   (c)   Radio antennas and associated equipment, including supporting
structures.  This exception does not include facilities extending to and from
such equipment.
   (d)   Temporary utility facilities used for supplying services to new
construction, or for maintaining services during periods of restoration or
replacement.
   (e)   Electric transmission lines, three phase distribution lines,
substations and switching stations.
   (f)   Electric and telephone service terminals and splices in pedestals;
enclosed padmounted distribution transformers; padmounted distribution
equipment; riser facilities for connecting approved or existing distribution
lines to distribution lines.
   (g)   Service equipment and connections mounted against walls of buildings
served, including electric risers and meters and communiction or television
risers and terminals.
(Ord. 93-20.  Passed 6-1-93.)
945.03  VARIANCE AND MODIFICATIONS.
   (a)   The Planning Commission may grant a variance from the provisions and
requirements of this chapter upon appplication of a subdivider, developer or
utility, provided that the Commission finds that all of the following
conditions apply:
      (1)   There are special conditions or circumstances applicable to the
land, the development thereof or the use of the land to be serviced.
      (2)   The granting of the variance is necessary for the preservation and
enjoyment of substantial property rights.
      (3)   The granting of the variance will not affect adversely the public
health or safety or be detrimental to the public welfare, or injurious to
property or improvements.
   (b)   During the construction and installation of an approved utility
facility(s), the Electric Utility Manager and/or the Public Service Director,
with the approval of the City Manager, may modify the application of this
chapter when, during construction, it is discovered that the installation of
such underground facility(s) would be impractical or impossible due to the
nature of soil or rock formations in the area, the presence of impeding
underground drainage facilities, environmental dangers and impediments of like
nature.
(Ord. 93-20.  Passed 6-1-93.)
945.04  MAINTENANCE.
   (a)   All utility facilities shall be installed and maintained in accordance
with the provisions of this chapter, the National Electrical Safety Code and
good utility practices.
   (b)   The Electric Utility Manager is authorized and directed to promulgate
rules and standards for the construction of underground utility facilities.
(Ord. 93-20.  Passed 6-1-93.)
945.99  PENALTY.
   (a)   No subdivision approval shall be granted and no plats shall be
approved unless such subdivision or plat complies with the terms of this
chapter.
   (b)   Any person, firm or corporation who violates, disobeys, omits,
neglects or refuses to comply with the terms of this chapter shall be fined not
less than fifty dollars ($50.00).  Each day of violation of any section of this
chapter shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 93-20.  Passed 6-1-93.)
CHAPTER 947
Data Center, Fiber Network and Conduit Network
947.01   Definitions.
947.02   Rates.
947.03   Tampering with data center, fiber network, conduit network;
unauthorized connections.
947.04   Access to fiber network; inspections.
947.05   Penalty.
947.01  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this Chapter:
   (a)   “Data Center” means the building and appurtenances located at 35
Collegeview Road, Westerville, Ohio 43081, used to house computer systems and
associated components, such as telecommunications and storage systems,
redundancy mechanisms, environmental controls (e.g., air conditioning and fire
suppression) and security devices.
   (b)   “Fiber Network” means the City owned fiber communications equipment,
cable, facilities, pathways, connections and equipment providing high speed
data connectivity which is installed in various locations, both within and
outside the City.
   (c)   “Conduit Network” means the City owned infrastructure of conduit,
pipes, ducts, cable trays, manholes, handholes, rights of way and areas of
access containing or available for installation of fiber optic cable.
(Ord. 2011-39.  Passed 10-4-11.)
947.02   RATES.
   (a)   (1)   The schedule of rates and charges on file with the Clerk of the
City and incorporated herein by reference is hereby adopted.
      (2)   The rates and charges provided for above are applicable for
contracts for a term not to exceed twenty years. The City Manager and his
authorized agents are authorized to enter into term contracts, not to exceed
twenty years utilizing the rates then in effect provided that the City Manager
deems such contract to be fair and reasonable.
      (3)   After giving consideration to factors including but not limited to
the amount of annual revenue anticipated in the contract, the size of the
customer and potential for additional future sales, the length of the contract
term, economic development opportunities, and any other factors normally
considered in the formation of a business contract, the City Manager and his
authorized agents are authorized to enter into contracts which offer a
discount, however, after discounts, the revenue received must meet or exceed
the cost of goods sold and debt service by at least fifteen percent (15%)
(“Sales Discount”). The City Manager is not authorized to approve a transaction
that exceeds the Sales Discount without City Council approval unless it is to
support an economic development project.
         A.   An economic development project is defined as a project that
results in job creation, retention and/or investment. The amount of other city
revenue from this project (income tax, property tax, etc.) must cover the
amount exceeding the sales discount.
         B.   WeConnect revenue from projects that receive the economic
development discount must still cover the cost of goods sold and debt service.
      (4)   Nothing in this Chapter shall impair any contract in effect at the
time of adoption, provided renewals of existing contracts shall be subject to
the rates and charges in effect at the time of renewal.
   (b)   Terms and Conditions. The City Manager is authorized to promulgate
terms and conditions relative to the lease, use and provision of products and
services for the data center, fiber network and conduit network, which terms
and conditions are hereby incorporated by reference, as if fully rewritten
herein. Such terms and provisions may include, but not be limited to: the
nature and substance of the contracts, terms of service, service connections,
deposits, billing, nonpayment, disconnection of service and service charges.
   (c)   Products, Services and Contract Provisions. Prior to the lease, use or
provision of products and services for the data center, fiber network and/or
conduit network, the customer shall enter into one or more written agreements,
each in a form and substance satisfactory to the City Manager or the City’s
authorized agent, each of whom are authorized to execute such agreements on
behalf of the City. Such agreements shall include but not be limited to: a
master capacity fiber lease and service agreement, a master capacity conduit
lease and service agreement, dark fiber agreements and agreements relating to
the provision of data center products and services. Such agreements shall
provide for, among other things, rates, terms, requirements, discounts and
default provisions.
   (d)   Connections. The City Manager is hereby authorized and directed to set
and exact charges for the connection to the fiber network upon the granting of
permission to connect such property to the fiber network. Such charges shall be
set and exacted based upon the cost to the City or its agent incurred in making
such connection. The City Manager, in conjunction with the Finance Director,
shall reimburse the City’s authorized agents for the cost associated with the
construction of such connections and the City Manager or his authorized
designee is authorized to recoup the costs of constructing such connections
through the charges set in Section
947.02 (a). The City Manager, or his authorized designee, is hereby authorized
and directed to provide for reasonable and appropriate economic development
incentives related to the construction and installation of connections on a
case by case basis to encourage and foster the continued growth of the City’s
business community.
(Ord. 2011-39.  Passed 10-4-11; Ord. 2016-09.  Passed 4-5-16.)
947.03   TAMPERING WITH DATA CENTER, FIBER NETWORK, CONDUIT NETWORK;
UNAUTHORIZED CONNECTIONS.
   No person, without the consent of the City or its authorized agent, shall
connect, tap, tamper, reconnect, sever, open, interfere or otherwise make any
unauthorized connections, attachments or alterations to the data center, fiber
network or conduit network.
(Ord. 2011-39.  Passed 10-4-11.)
947.04   ACCESS TO FIBER NETWORK; INSPECTIONS.
   (a)   The Director of Public Utilities and his or her authorized agents are
authorized to install the fiber network and provide for the necessary
connection to, and maintenance for, any and all properties served by the fiber
network.
   (b)   The Director of Public Utilities or his or her authorized agents are
authorized to enter upon any land and into any building which has heretofore,
or is hereafter, connected directly or indirectly to the fiber network for the
purpose of installing, removing, repairing, maintaining, and inspecting the
connections to the fiber network.
   (c)   Service may be terminated for failure of a customer to provide land or
building access to the fiber network for the purpose of installing connections
to, or maintaining, the fiber network, after being given notice and a
reasonable time in which to comply with such notice.
   (d)   The customer shall pay the appropriate service termination and
resumption charges as provided in this chapter for denying access to the
Director of Public Utilities or authorized agents for the purpose of installing
connections to, and maintaining, the fiber network.
(Ord. 2011-39.  Passed 10-4-11.)
947.05   PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this Chapter, or fails, refuses, or
neglects to comply with the reasonable directions or demands of the City
Manager or his authorized agent or designee issued pursuant to the provisions
of this Chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree. A
separate offense shall be deemed committed for each day that a violation occurs
or continues.
(Ord. 2011-39.  Passed 10-4-11.)
TITLE FIVE - Other Public Services
         
Chap. 961.   Solid Waste Collection and Disposal.

CHAPTER 961
Solid Waste Collection and Disposal
961.01   Definitions.
961.02   Accumulation of waste;  containers.
961.03   Recycling program.

961.05   Ownership of solid waste.
961.06   Hazardous and infectious waste disposal.
